CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: This result leads us to conclude that PTATDPP retains a higher crystalline nature in the blend with PC71BM , affording a better hole transporting pathway and thus exhibiting a higher J SC and FF than PTAFDPP. When the morphologies of active layers were observed by transmission electron microscopy , the PTATDPP : PC71BM blend shows clearly a fibril nanostructure ( fibril width ∼ 30 nm ) with the formation of a bi-continuous network , whereas the PTAFDPP : PC71BM blend shows a phase - separated morphology without the formation of distinct nanostructures , as shown in Fig. 5. It is well recognized that the nanoscale phase separation with a fibril structure is favourable for an efficient exciton dissociation and charge transport which are the prerequisites for high J SC and FF of PSCs. Therefore , the high FF ( 0.68 ) of PTATDPP - based device arises mainly from the efficient charge - carrier mobility and the formation of a nanoscale fibril structure of PTATDPP. To further evaluate the potential of PTATDPP as an electron donor material for PSCs , we fabricated a non-fullerene PSC device by blending PTATDPP with a non-fullerene small molecular electron acceptor , 2,2′9,9′-tetra(undecan-6-yl)- [ 5,5′bianthra (2,1,9-def:6,5,10-d′e′f′)diisoquinolin]-1,1′,3,3′,8,8′,10,10′- (2H,2′H,9H,9′H)-octaone ( di-PBI ). 38 As can be seen in Fig. 6a , PTATDPP and di-PBI have well - matched energy levels with a LUMO - LUMO offset of 0.4 eV , 39 which is enough for exciton dissociation , and also exhibit complementary absorption , i.e. , di-PDI and PTATDPP absorb 400-600 nm and 600-800 nm , respectively. As a consequence , the blend film ( 1 : 2 in weight ratio ) exhibits a broad light absorption from 400 to 800 nm. The compatibility of PTATDPP and di-PBI as an electron donor and an acceptor , respectively , was also examined by monitoring the photoluminescence ( PL ) quenching of each compound in the blend film. As shown in Fig. 6c , the blend film shows excellent PL quenching over 95% of each PL from PTATDPP and di-PBI , indicating that photogenerated excitons from both PTATDPP and di-PBI are readily dissociated into free carriers at the interface of two materials. The non-fullerene PSC fabricated from the blend of PTATDPP and di-PBI exhibits a PCE of 4.23% with V OC = 0.77 V , J SC = 9.8 mA cm^-2 and FF = 0.56 ( Fig. 7 ). Interestingly , the blend morphology of PTATDPP and di-PDI as observed from atomic force microscopy ( AFM ) and TEM reveals that PTATDPP forms a well - developed interconnected BHJ morphology with a fibrillar nanostructure ( Fig. S4 and S5 † ). This fibril morphology affords the effective exciton dissociation as observed from the PL quenching experiment.

Let's think step by step.

Sure! Let's identify the "Material Name" entities in the paragraph:

1. PTATDPP (mentioned 7 times)
2. PC71BM (mentioned once)
3. PTAFDPP (mentioned once)
4. di-PBI (mentioned once)
5. PTATDPP : PC71BM (mentioned once)
6. PTATDPP : di-PBI (mentioned once)

Note that some of these entities may appear in different forms, such as abbreviations or chemical formulas, but they are all distinct material names.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

Of course! Here are the material names mentioned in the paragraph:

1. PTATDPP
2. di-PBI

These are the only material names mentioned in the paragraph.

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Certainly! Here are the material names mentioned in the paragraph, presented in a Markdown table with one column "Material Name":

| Material Name |
| --- |
| PTATDPP |
| di-PBI |

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any further questions.

Paragraph: This result leads us to conclude that PTATDPP retains a higher crystalline nature in the blend with PC71BM , affording a better hole transporting pathway and thus exhibiting a higher J SC and FF than PTAFDPP. When the morphologies of active layers were observed by transmission electron microscopy , the PTATDPP : PC71BM blend shows clearly a fibril nanostructure ( fibril width ∼ 30 nm ) with the formation of a bi-continuous network , whereas the PTAFDPP : PC71BM blend shows a phase - separated morphology without the formation of distinct nanostructures , as shown in Fig. 5. It is well recognized that the nanoscale phase separation with a fibril structure is favourable for an efficient exciton dissociation and charge transport which are the prerequisites for high J SC and FF of PSCs. Therefore , the high FF ( 0.68 ) of PTATDPP - based device arises mainly from the efficient charge - carrier mobility and the formation of a nanoscale fibril structure of PTATDPP. To further evaluate the potential of PTATDPP as an electron donor material for PSCs , we fabricated a non-fullerene PSC device by blending PTATDPP with a non-fullerene small molecular electron acceptor , 2,2′9,9′-tetra(undecan-6-yl)- [ 5,5′bianthra (2,1,9-def:6,5,10-d′e′f′)diisoquinolin]-1,1′,3,3′,8,8′,10,10′- (2H,2′H,9H,9′H)-octaone ( di-PBI ). 38 As can be seen in Fig. 6a , PTATDPP and di-PBI have well - matched energy levels with a LUMO - LUMO offset of 0.4 eV , 39 which is enough for exciton dissociation , and also exhibit complementary absorption , i.e. , di-PDI and PTATDPP absorb 400-600 nm and 600-800 nm , respectively. As a consequence , the blend film ( 1 : 2 in weight ratio ) exhibits a broad light absorption from 400 to 800 nm. The compatibility of PTATDPP and di-PBI as an electron donor and an acceptor , respectively , was also examined by monitoring the photoluminescence ( PL ) quenching of each compound in the blend film. As shown in Fig. 6c , the blend film shows excellent PL quenching over 95% of each PL from PTATDPP and di-PBI , indicating that photogenerated excitons from both PTATDPP and di-PBI are readily dissociated into free carriers at the interface of two materials. The non-fullerene PSC fabricated from the blend of PTATDPP and di-PBI exhibits a PCE of 4.23% with V OC = 0.77 V , J SC = 9.8 mA cm^-2 and FF = 0.56 ( Fig. 7 ). Interestingly , the blend morphology of PTATDPP and di-PDI as observed from atomic force microscopy ( AFM ) and TEM reveals that PTATDPP forms a well - developed interconnected BHJ morphology with a fibrillar nanostructure ( Fig. S4 and S5 † ). This fibril morphology affords the effective exciton dissociation as observed from the PL quenching experiment.

Let's think step by step.

Sure, I'd be happy to help you identify the property names of materials in the paragraph! Here are the materials mentioned in the paragraph along with their property names:

1. PTATDPP (Poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene)) - Polymer
2. PC71BM (Poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):Polystyrene sulfonate) - Polymer blend
3. PTAFDPP (Poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):Fluorinated poly(4-vinylphenol)) - Polymer blend
4. 2,2′9,9′-tetra(undecan-6-yl)-[5,5′bianthra(2,1,9-def:6,5,10-d′e′f′)diisoquinolin]-1,1′,3,3′,8,8′,10,10′- (2H,2′H,9H,9′H)-octaone (di-PBI) - Small molecule electron acceptor
5. LUMO (Lowest Unoccupied Molecular Orbital) - Energy level
6. HOMO (Highest Occupied Molecular Orbital) - Energy level
7. ETL (Exciton Transport Layer) - Material layer
8. BHJ (Bulk Heterojunction) - Material structure
9. PCE (Power Conversion Efficiency) - Performance metric
10. V OC (Open Circuit Voltage) - Performance metric
11. J SC (Short Circuit Current) - Performance metric
12. FF (Fill Factor) - Performance metric

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any further questions.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Property Name of Material.

Sure, here are the entities that refer to the property name of a material in the text:

1. PTATDPP (Poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene)) - Property name of the polymer material.
2. PC71BM (Poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):Polystyrene sulfonate)) - Property name of the polymer blend material.
3. PTAFDPP (Poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):Fluorinated poly(4-vinylphenol)) - Property name of the polymer blend material.
4. di-PBI (2,2′9,9′-tetra(undecan-6-yl)-[5,5′bianthra(2,1,9-def:6,5,10-d′e′f′)diisoquinolin]-1,1′,3,3′,8,8′,10,10′- (2H,2′H,9H,9′H)-octaone) - Property name of the small molecule electron acceptor material.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any further questions.
